content:
I’ll just put out a potential time for a sync as a starting point we can work off. These are all the same time in different zones:

8:30pm 2020-07-28 (CEST)
11:30am 2020-07-28 (PDT)
2:30pm 2020-07-28 (EDT)
4:30am 2020-07-29 (AEST)

Via Zoom

Does this work for everyone interested? Of so I’ll create a room and calendar event for us.
OK for me
would prefer textual meeting if possible, (though i'm okay with zoom) and the time works for me

Oh, 2:30am (UTC+8) for me. I guess I will pass. I am surprised I don't know any of the timings @Ashley Mannix listed, CEST, PDT, EDT and AEST. UTC+0 is clear but those I don't understand, need to google.
@lzutao the timings ^
@pickfire Ah I should’ve listed UTC (which is 6:30pm 2020-07-28) :slight_smile:

I was wondering if we should try finding two times and alternate them, one that’s convenient for the US and one that’s convenient for Europe / Asia / Pacific? Since there’s no one time that’s going to suit all of us
@DPC I’m ok with text too if it’s more accessible for people. Does anybody else have any preferences either way on the format?

If any time that is fine for me, it would be before 5:00pm UTC, which is 1:00am for me. @Ashley Mannix No need to worry about me, I am just a spectator, not from any rust team yet, if I haven't sleep then I will join.
i can make that time
That should be fine for me, thanks for wrangling Ashley.
@XAMPPRocky Are there any tools or approaches you'd recommend for meetings these days? Like a shared Rust calendar to put things in, chat platforms, note taking apps?
@Ashley Mannix compiler team has its own calendar, and chat platform is decided by the team (normally the same platform where the team "resides" ) and hackmd is a common note taking app among teams
Thanks @DPC! hackmd is the thing I was really trying to remember the name of :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
@Ashley Mannix Another thing governance and core having been trying lately is having a GitHub project board for tracking the agenda. https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/projects/5

Hey all! I've created a Zoom meeting invite for the Libs meeting tomorrow (or today depending on your TZ):

Passcode: 796671
Invite link: https://zoom.us/j/97264998233?pwd=bDlpdk5aMGl5NVZlVkx4NXVBOUEwQT09
Agenda: https://hackmd.io/nfO1epfGSNu_rWMIxCW3Xg
Calendar Invite: meeting-97264998233.ics
Hopefully you can all edit the agenda :slight_smile: Let me know if I need to update anything for that to work!

@Ashley Mannix I’d like to propose creating a libs team charter as an agenda item.

The governance WG was discussing that we should reach out and help existing teams with creating a charter similar to what project groups have.

We thought that the libs and compiler teams would be a great place to start, since there have been large changes between these teams recently with the stdlib impl moving to the compiler team.

I also think this ties into a lot of the other agenda items, and would help in answering some of them.
I’ll put it in there!
Thanks Ashley for organizing and sending out the mail. I should check Zulip more regularly...
Is it planned to record and publish the meeting, by the way?
Oh and is there more context than this thread where such questions might have already been asked? ^_^

I set the Zoom meeting up to record and was going to take notes :slight_smile: I wasn’t sure what to try do with the recording yet but figured we could just go through the motions to figure out how we want things to go for a start. I should’ve gotten the mail out much sooner, but have everything all ready for next time! Which could be any time we’re up for it
There’s a “libs release cycle” stream with some context
Who's up for some Libs meeting in ~20mins? :smiley:
i'll be there!
https://hackmd.io/nfO1epfGSNu_rWMIxCW3Xg
Does anyone else see "Please wait" on the call?
not getting through :confused:
@Ashley Mannix
probably they didn't start the meeting yet :grinning:
@Ashley Mannix
(ping me if you're stuck in the waiting room)

Thanks to everyone who came along! Sorry for not watching the waiting room properly for a start... but were we happy with the time/format? Would we like to try some more regular Zulip meetings with the occasional Zoom?
It’s a thing! https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/
i am not sure there's much to discuss during meetings that requires zoom so a textual meeting might suffice and easier for people to follow up later on :slight_smile:
Oops I saw the email but failed to set a reminder for myself, sorry

@Simon Sapin All good! I think I sent the email out far too late to begin with. I'm _almost_ finished running through all our current unstable issues so maybe we can organize another meeting next week to triage some more of them?
@Ashley Mannix how do you think synchronous time should be used?

@Simon Sapin At this stage maybe we could use it to quickly run through a bunch of these unstable features and get a feel for whether we want to try push towards stabilizing or deprecating each one? That doesn't necessarily have to be synchronous though, but might make it quicker
Lately I’ve been less involved with Rust other than trying to keep up with rfcbot
Yeh, I think we have way too much unstable surface area for everyone to be across everything
I've captured all our tracking issues that have seen activity over the last 3 months (along with all our open RFCs) into this project: https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/projects/2
It's got a lot of stuff in it
And there are still ~70 older issues that aren't there yet because I ran out of steam

These ones with a nominated label are the issues someone has either explicitly asked about stabilization status on, or seemed self contained enough that I would go FCP them if I didn't want to create a pile of checkboxes for everyone all at once :) https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/projects/2?card_filter_query=label%3AI-nominated
Was anything concluded from 2021 edition?
nothing. None of the members had anything imporant they expected to happen in 2021 edition from libs side
Mainly the new prelude which will include TryInto and a slightly different implementation of the panic! macro.

I think it's something we should have a really good think about and see what we can and want to do. Just as examples, maybe some new APIs that move us to MaybeUninit over &mut and NonNull over *mut? A non-panicking std::mutex::Mutex? An alloc prelude that mirrors core?
We've got RustConf coming up in about 3 weeks (2020-08-20), maybe we could organize some planning around that to figure out what we'd want to try and do for the new edition?
Thanks for getting these set up again, @Ashley Mannix!
